Returnly.author: MaxwellWarnerCE
Returnly.name: Returnly API
Returnly.description:
# Introduction
The Returnly API enables developers to seamlessly receive and pass up-to-date returns and refunds data into the platforms you use to run your business. Optimize your returns and merchandise strategies, maximize your technology investments and streamline your business with our [Returns](#tag/Returns), [Requests](#tag/Requests) & [Refunds](#tag/Refunds) APIs

# Common Use Cases
 * Update your OMS with real-time returns data
 * Get up to date returns status in real-time
 * Leverage granular return data to optimize your current merchandise initiatives
 * Track shipping and delivery of product returns
 * Feed your CRM systems with real-time customer returns data
 * Manage inventory predictably by monitoring returns and understanding which items have resell potential
 * Manage inventory predictably by monitoring returns and understanding which items have resell potential
 * Automate order refunds by connecting your warehouse scan system to the Returnly Refund API

# Getting Started
## Customers
You will need an Enterprise Returnly license in order to access our API. Please contact your Returnly representative to gain access.

TrackTik.author: MaxwellWarnerCE
TrackTik.name: TrackTik API 2
TrackTik.description:
# Introduction
The TrackTik API is built on HTTP. Our API is RESTful. It has predictable
resource URLs. It returns HTTP response codes to indicate errors. It also
accepts and returns JSON in the HTTP body. You can use your favorite
HTTP/REST library for your programming language to use TrackTik's API, or
you can use one of our SDKs.

Most of the objects are supported by an API which is documented and available for use so that you
may automate any work flows necessary. This document contains the most commonly
integrated resources.

# Authentication
To use the API, you will need to receive your API token.
You can generate additional API keys, and delete API keys (as you may
need to rotate your keys in the future). You authenticate to the
TrackTik API by providing your secret token in the request header or in a query parameter.

TrackTik now supports two forms of authentication: header token and query parameters token


# Service patterns
 

```
GET /entity-tag
# Return a collection of entities
# Service: EntityCollection
```
```
GET /entity-tag/{id} 
# Return an entity detail
# Service: SingleEntity
```

```
POST /entity-tag/{id}/action/{actionName}
# Runs an action on a model @todo
# Service: Action
```

```
POST /entity-tag/batch/{actionName}
# Runs a batch action on some models defined by a filter or a list of IDS @todo
# Service: ActionBatch
```

```
GET /entity-tag/action/{actionName}
# Returns the action definition
# Service: ActionDefinition
```

# Sorting Results

When calling the collection services, you can sort the results by using a coma seperated value of fields
- For descendant order, append "-" before the field
```
GET /resource?sort=-createdAt
# Sorts the results by createdAt desc
```
- You can add relations or more fields in the request
```
GET /resource?sort=-createdAt, region.name
# Sorts the results by createdAt desc and then region.name ascendant
```


# Filtering Results

You can filter the API using all fields 
```
GET /resource?customId=ABC001
# Returns objects with customId = to ABC001.
```
You can also filter by relations
```
GET /resource?region.id=15
# Returns objects with region ID = 15
```

You can chain filters. Filters are chainned using the AND conditions. 
```
GET /resource?region.id=15&createdAt=2015-01-01
# Returns objects with region ID = 15 created on 2015-01-01
```

# :IN filters

Sometimes, you need to query more than one value. You can use the "in" pseudo operator in your filter. 
```
GET /resource?region.id:in=15,10
# Returns objects with region ID = 15 or ID=10
```

# Date Filters

**Filtering by a date**
```
GET /entity-tag?created={{date}}
# Returns objects created on that date
```

```
/entity-tag?created:before={{date}}
# Returns objects created before that date. Non-inclusive
```

```
/entity-tag?created:after={{date}}
# Returns objects created after that date. Non-inclusive
```

```
/entity-tag?created:between={{date1}},{{date2}}
# Returns objects created between the 2 dates. Inclusive
```

**Supported date format**

```
2018-01-02 # International format
12/01/2018 # US Format
01-12-2018 # UK Format
```

**Supported time formats**

```
23:30 # 24hr format
11:30am # US format
2330 # Short (24hr) format
```

**Relative Formats**
For a full list, please refer to [this guide](http://www.php.net/manual/en/datetime.formats.relative.php)
```
"yesterday 14:00"
"last day of next month"
```



# Scope Filters

Scopes are pre-made filters that can be applied to any services that return a collection of entities.
- Each entity defines their own scopes. 
- You can filter by multiple scopes

**Example scopes for the **shift** entity**

- LATE
- PUBLISHED
- NOT_PUBLISHED
- VACANT
- WORKING
- MISSED
- NOT
- HAS_OVERTIME
- ACKNOWLEDGED
- NOT_ACKNOWLEDGED
- TIMESHEET_NOT_APPROVED
- TIMESHEET_APPROVED
- TODAY
- COMPLETED

**Unique scope usage**

```
GET /shift?scope=LATE
# Return the list of current late shift
```

```
GET /shift?scope=VACANT
# Return the list of vacant shifts
```

**Multiple scopes usage** 
- Separate by a coma (,) for AND condition
- Separate by a pipe (|) for OR condition

```
GET /shift?scope=VACANT,STARTING_SOON
# Return the list of vacant shifts that are vacant AND are starting soon
```

```
GET /shift?scope=VACANT|MISSED
# Return the list of vacant shifts that are vacant OR were missed
```

# On-demand fields

On-demand fields can be added to the API object output by specifying with the `include` query parameter.
```
GET /employees?include=employmentProfile
```
The employee object will now include a `employmentProfile` property. You can specify multiple on-demand fields by separating them with a coma.
```
GET /employees?include=employmentProfile,address
```

AcuityScheduling.author: avinashch0216
AcuityScheduling.name: Acuity Scheduling
